item.title: Inside the Pentagon’s Scramble to Deal With Boat Strike Survivors
item.description: Officials initially weighed sending survivors of U.S. attacks on boats suspected of drug smuggling to a notorious prison in El Salvador, to keep them away from American courts.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave, Edward Wong and Maria Abi-Habib
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:description: Recent news reports on strike orders given by Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth have raised questions of potential war crimes.

item.title: Democrats Say Hegseth Balked at Call for Full Video of Boat Strike
item.description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth briefed congressional leaders on Tuesday about the monthslong military campaign targeting people suspected of being drug traffickers at sea.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth at the Capitol on Tuesday.

item.title: Legal Groups Sue Justice Dept. for Secret Memo Justifying Boat Strikes
item.description: “The public deserves to know how the Trump administration has justified the outright murder of civilians as lawful,” the organizations said in their lawsuit.
item.dc:creator: Jonah E. Bromwich
item.media:description: The lawsuit, filed by the American Civil Liberties Union and other legal groups, seeks the release of a secret memo that provides a legal rationale for the Trump administration’s strikes.

item.title: Nobel Peace Prize for Venezuela’s María Corina Machado Draws Criticism
item.description: María Corina Machado is being honored for her push for democracy even as she backs President Trump’s military buildup and aggressive campaign against Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky and Henrik Pryser Libell
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The opposition leader María Corina Machado in her office in Caracas last year.

item.title: Trump Says Americans Are Doing Great, Even as Views on the Economy Sour
item.description: President Trump’s speech in Pennsylvania was meant to alleviate concerns about affordability. But he kept wandering off script and dwelling on his favorite targets, like immigration.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: President Trump delivering remarks on the economy at the Mount Airy Casino Resort in Mount Pocono, Pa., on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump Administration Withdraws Plan to Overhaul Homeless Aid
item.description: The abrupt decision to revise the plan added new uncertainty and possible delays into the government’s distribution of $3.9 billion in homelessness relief.
item.dc:creator: Jason DeParle
item.media:credit: Aaron Wojack for The New York Times
item.media:description: A homeless camp outside Suisun City, Calif., last month.

item.title: Stephen Miller’s Stock Sale Raises Questions, Ethics Experts Say
item.description: Mr. Miller, one of President Trump’s top advisers, sold shares in the mining company MP Materials following a lucrative deal between the company and the government.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: Stephen Miller, one of the president’s top advisers, sold shares of a mining company after it had begun negotiations with the government, raising concerns among ethics experts.

item.title: Taiwan Invokes National Security Law to Protect TSMC Trade Secrets
item.description: An executive left TSMC for Intel. Taiwan’s government says that could threaten its national security.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan Tobin and Xinyun Wu
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: The authorities in Taiwan are taking a stronger hand in protecting the prized technology of the chip maker TSMC.

item.title: Chip Company Plotted to Send Technology to China, Ex-C.E.O. Says
item.description: The former chief executive of Nexperia, a Dutch chipmaker, said Dutch officials had known for years that the company’s Chinese owner sought to move its technology to China.
item.dc:creator: Mara Hvistendahl and Joy Dong
item.media:description: On a production line of the Dutch semiconductor company Nexperia in Hamburg, Germany, last year. Dutch officials seized the company in September.

item.title: Trump’s Nvidia Chip Deal Reverses Decades of Technology Restrictions
item.description: President Trump’s decision to allow Nvidia to sell its chips to China has raised questions about whether he is prioritizing short-term economic gain over long-term American security interests.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump with Jensen Huang, the chief executive of Nvidia, at the White House in April.

item.title: Asserting a Personal Role in Warner Bros. Battle, Trump Seeks to Expand His Powers Again
item.description: The move comes as the Supreme Court also appears poised to put antitrust enforcement by the Federal Trade Commission under his control.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Aleksey Kondratyev for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Warner Bros. Studios complex in Burbank, Calif.

item.title: The Battle for Warner Bros. Discovery
item.description: Nicole Sperling, a Times reporter who covers Hollywood and the streaming revolution, breaks down the competing bids from Netflix and Paramount to buy Warner Bros. Discovery.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling, Edward Vega, Laura Salaberry, Jon Hazell and Chris Orr

item.title: At State Dept., a Typeface Falls Victim in the War Against Woke
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio called the Biden-era move to the sans serif typeface “wasteful,” casting the return to Times New Roman as part of a push to stamp out diversity efforts.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio at the White House last month.

item.title: Democrat Eileen Higgins Wins Miami Runoff Election to Become City’s First Female Mayor
item.description: Eileen Higgins, a former Miami-Dade County commissioner, will also be the city’s first female mayor and the first non-Hispanic mayor since the 1990s.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Eileen Higgins in Miami in November.

item.title: Trump’s Speech on Economy Veers Into an Anti-Immigrant Tirade
item.description: President Trump vacillated between demonizing immigrants and assuring a crowd of his supporters that life was better than ever under his administration.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:description: President Trump spoke to his supporters at the Mount Airy Casino Resort in Mount Pocono, Pa., on Tuesday.

item.title: Canada Plans to Fast-Track Immigration for US H1-B Visa Holders in New Talent Drive
item.description: The government says it will fast-track immigration for U.S. H-1B visa holders and spend more than $1 billion to attract researchers from the United States and the rest of the world.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: The University of Toronto, one of the world’s best-ranked academic institutions, picked up several top professors from Ivy League schools this year, including two from M.I.T.

item.title: Why Trump Accounts, as Currently Planned, Risk Leaving Out Many Children
item.description: Michael and Susan Dell are donating $6.25 billion to American children via the accounts, but the details matter.
item.dc:creator: Claire Cain Miller and Jonah Smith
item.media:description: Researchers suggest enrolling children automatically, but that’s not the current plan.

item.title: Mackenzie Scott Announces $7 Billion of Giving This Year
item.description: The philanthropist known for donating to historically Black colleges and nonprofits working on climate change offered the news by updating an October blog post.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Kulish and Theodore Schleifer
item.media:description: The philanthropist MacKenzie Scott.

item.title: Rod Paige, Education Secretary Who Defended ‘No Child Left Behind,’ Dies at 92
item.description: He was both the first Black person and the first educator to hold the cabinet position, but resigned amid discord over George W. Bush’s No Child Left Behind.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden
item.media:description: Rod Paige, the education secretary, in Nashville in 2004.

item.title: Seattle’s Plans for a Pride Match at World Cup Infuriates Iran and Egypt
item.description: The two countries, which criminalize homosexuality and impose severe punishments for it, were picked to play on a day celebrating L.G.B.T.Q. communities.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Iran learned its group at the FIFA World Cup draw last week in Washington, D.C.

item.title: Trump Calls Europe ‘Decaying’ and Suggests ‘Size Will Win’ in Ukraine War
item.description: President Trump’s comments deepened his rift with mainstream European leaders over defense and Ukraine policy.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: President Trump with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and other European leaders during a meeting at the White House earlier this year.

item.title: Ukraine Could Be ‘Ready for Elections,’ Zelensky Says
item.description: The Ukrainian president told reporters that a vote could be held in 60 to 90 days if the country received security protections from the United States.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine speaking at the White House in Washington, D.C., in October.

item.title: 2025 Best Dishes in America
item.description: Crispy fish ssam, knife-cut noodles and more of our favorite bites from a year of eating.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: 2025 Best Desserts in America
item.description: Dulce de leche flan, cherry pie and more of our favorite sweets of the year.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: What Streaming TV Could Learn from ‘Mad Men’
item.description: The classic show arrived on HBO Max with an embarrassing remastering error. But the show’s creative mastery remains undeniable.
item.dc:creator: James Poniewozik
item.media:description: Jon Hamm in “Mad Men,” now streaming on HBO Max.

item.title: Trump Picked This Fight With Maduro. He Can’t Back Down.
item.description: If the Trump administration allows Nicolás Maduro to endure, it would signal that a criminal dictatorship masquerading as a state can stare down the United States and win.
item.dc:creator: Ricardo Hausmann and Jose Morales-Arilla
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado and the presidential candidate Edmundo González at a rally in Caracas, Venezuela, in July 2024.

item.title: Late Night Doesn’t Want to Sweat at the Airport
item.description: Ronny Chieng dissed new fitness plans from the Trump administration for travelers in American airports: “We can’t even walk to the gate. They had to invent floors that walk for us.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)

item.title: Student Is Killed in Shooting at Kentucky State University
item.description: A suspect who is not a student was arrested after the shooting in Frankfort, Ky., the police said. The university said that a second student was critically injured.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson, Rylee Kirk and Corinne Boyer
item.media:description: The Kentucky State University campus in Frankfort, Ky., where the police responded to a shooting on Tuesday afternoon.

item.title: DéLana R.A. Dameron, Writer of the Black South, Dies at 40
item.description: An award-winning poet and writer of fiction, she moonlighted as a competitive horsewoman and owned a horse farm outside Columbia, S.C.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: Bird Flu Is Suspected After Vulture Carcasses Sat Rotting Outside Ohio School
item.description: The birds lingered for days at a Catholic school near Cincinnati as agencies haggled over who was responsible for removing them. Officials said the public health risk was low.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor

item.title: End of Major Corruption Case Embarrasses N.Y. Cannabis Regulators
item.description: A case against the Long Island-based cannabis company Omnium Health was halted on the eve of trial. A judge on Tuesday held off on dropping the matter.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Southall
item.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Omnium Health, in Hauppauge, N.Y., has been the focus of a major state corruption investigation.
